question: As a food safety expert, I'm curious: between ozone and chlorine treatments, which one leaves chemical residues on processed food products?
generated_answer: Neither ozone nor chlorine leaves chemical residues on processed food products. Ozone reverts to pure clean oxygen after acting as an oxidizing agent, and it has received the USDA’s Organic Certification. Chlorine, while it can leave a detectable chemical residue on product, is approved by the USDA as a very safe and effective way to kill or inhibit the growth of any potential bacteria and foodborne pathogens, like Salmonella. It works very quickly and then dissipates. Studies have determined that there are no residues of hazardous substances in poultry meat treated with chlorine-based compounds.
ground_truth_answer: Ozone leaves no chemical residue on food products as it reverts to pure clean oxygen after acting as an oxidizing agent. In contrast, chlorine leaves a detectable chemical residue on products and is prohibited for imports in many countries. However, studies on chlorine-washed chicken specifically have determined that there are no residues of hazardous substances in poultry meat treated with chlorine-based compounds.
